message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother's positive HbsAg and anti-HbcAg status suggests she has chronic hepatitis B, while the positive hepatitis C RNA and reactive antibody suggests she also has hepatitis C. The newborn should receive hepatitis B IVIG and vaccine to protect against hepatitis B, but ledipisvir/sofosbuvir is not indicated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother is positive for hepatitis B and C, which can be transmitted to the newborn. Administration of hepatitis B IVIG and vaccine is recommended. There is no indication for ledipisvir/sofosbuvir in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother is positive for both HbsAg and anti-HbcAg, indicating a chronic hepatitis B infection. The baby should receive both hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B IVIG within 12 hours of birth. The mother's hepatitis C status should also be monitored, but no treatment is necessary for the newborn at this time. Ledipisvir/sofosbuvir is not indicated for hepatitis B infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the mother is hepatitis B surface antigen positive, the newborn needs to receive hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine within 12 hours of birth. The presence of hepatitis C RNA and reactive antibody indicate that the newborn may have been exposed to hepatitis C, but there is no specific treatment recommended for newborns in this scenario. Ledipasvir/sofosbuvir is a medication used to treat chronic hepatitis C in adults, not given to newborns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother is positive for hepatitis B surface antigen and anti-hepatitis B core antigen, indicating that she is a hepatitis B carrier. The newborn should receive hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) and hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth. Hepatitis C is not an indication for prophylaxis, and ledipasvir/sofosbuvir is not indicated in the neonatal period.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother's positive HbsAg and anti-HbcAg indicate chronic hepatitis B infection, while the hepatitis C RNA and antibody indicate current Hepatitis C infection. The newborn should receive Hepatitis B IVIG and vaccine, as the risk of transmission of Hepatitis B is high during delivery. The ledipisvir/sofosbuvir is used to treat Hepatitis C, but is not necessary for the newborn at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother’s hepatitis B and C status suggests that the newborn may be at risk for infection. Vaccination is recommended for all infants born to mothers with hepatitis B. Hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) and hepatitis B vaccine should be given to neonates born to HBV-infected mothers within 12 hours of birth. In this case, the baby should receive hepatitis B IVIG and vaccine. There is no indication for treatment with ledipasvir/sofosbuvir as this is used for hepatitis C treatment in adults.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother’s positive HbsAg and anti-HbcAg results indicate that she has chronic hepatitis B infection. However, the hepatitis C results do not indicate that she has a chronic infection, only that she has been exposed to the virus. Therefore, the newborn should receive hepatitis B IVIG and vaccine to prevent infection from the mother’s chronic hepatitis B. The ledipasvir/sofosbuvir option is incorrect as it is a treatment for hepatitis C, which is not necessary for the newborn at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the mother is positive for HbsAg and anti-HbcAg, the newborn should receive hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and the hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth, and subsequent vaccine doses at 1 and 6 months after birth. The presence of hepatitis C RNA and antibody does not require treatment for the newborn. Ledipisvir/sofosbuvir is used for the treatment of chronic hepatitis C in adults.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother's positive HbsAg and anti-HbcAg suggest she has chronic hepatitis B infection, and hepatitis C RNA detected along with reactive antibody suggest she also has chronic hepatitis C. The newborn child should receive hepatitis B IVIG and vaccine to prevent transmission of hepatitis B, but not ledipisvir/sofosbuvir as it is a treatment for hepatitis C and not a preventive measure. The presence of hepatitis C in the mother does not require immediate action for the newborn.
